subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] What language tags for Quikscript?
msgSnippet: ... I recommend submitting an ISO 15924 request form and getting a proper (non-private-use) code element (subtag) assigned.  The form can be submitted
messageBody:
Nathan Sharfi scripsit:

> I've been looking over script tags and how to mint
> them, especially the instructions for private use on
> <https://tools.ietf.org/html/bcp47#section-2.2.3> Do en-Qaas,
> en-Qaas-US, en-Qaas-GB, and so on look reasonable?

I recommend submitting an ISO 15924 request form and
getting a proper (non-private-use) code element (subtag)
assigned. The form can be submitted electronically at
<http://unicode.org/iso15924/iso15924form.html>.
It's short and sweet, and approval usually comes
through fairly quickly.

One question to be answered first is whether Quikscript should be coded
as a variant of Shavian script, in the same sense that German Fraktur
script is coded as a variant of Latin script. ISO 15924 defines a
script variant as a "particular form of one script which is so distinctive
a rendering as to almost be considered a unique script in itself".
I think Quikscript qualifies. If so, I think we should request the code
Shaq (variants differ in the last letter only), if not, the code Quik.

This issue is independent of Unicode unification or disunification
and does not prejudice it either way. Fraktur letters are unified with
ordinary Latin, but the three script variants of Georgian are not unified
in Unicode.

--
You are a child of the universe no less John Cowan
than the trees and all other acyclic http://www.ccil.org/~cowan
graphs; you have a right to be here. cowan@...
--DeXiderata by Sean McGrath
